Dear Ms. Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing adequate services, resulting in a large
number of youths going to the emergency department.
Investigation On 11/22/24 Complainant reported a concerning number of
youths from Vista Maria were dropped at local hospital emergency
departments within the last 48 hours. There is concern the agency
is not providing proper care and programming to prevent the youth
from needing care in the emergency department.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator, Rights Officer, and Quality Manager were
contacted on 11/22/24 by email to obtain the names of youth that
were seen at a hospital from 11/19/24-11/22/24.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth A reported participating in therapy one or two days per
week. Activities on the unit included coloring, drawing, playing
games, going outside, and watching movies. Youth A stated an
outside group came to the unit at times to do organized activities
with youth. Youth A stated groups were held several times per
week, but she refused to participate. Youth A attended online
school, due to ongoing behavioral issues, but wished to attend
school in person again. Youth A reported behaviors include hitting
staff, self-harming, fighting, and breaking things on the unit. Youth
A stated police were called to the unit when youth physically
attacked staff and would not stop, or when youth were self-
harming or suicidal. Youth were sent to the hospital when suicidal,
self-harming, or if injured from fighting a peer. Youth A stated in
her experience, police always transported youth to the hospital
and agency staff followed behind in a car, then stayed with youth
while at the hospital. When asked what the agency could do to
better support her and decrease incidents, Youth A stated,
2

“nothing, they can’t stop me, I’m crazy.” Youth A indicated when
her mind was made up, there was nothing staff could do or say to
stop her. If Youth A wanted to hurt someone, or tear up the unit,
she would do it no matter what. Youth A stated staff talk to her,
offer the calming room, her therapist for support, or other activities
to do, but she would not listen to staff. Youth A could not think of
anything staff could do differently to help her. However, Youth A
felt the program could do a better job of rewarding youth with good
behavior.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth B reported participating in therapy weekly and found it to be
helpful. Youth A stated groups were held daily, but she did not
always participate as it was usually an activity on paper that she
did not find helpful. Youth B reported she was able to make phone
calls to family every day, and she was able to draw or read daily.
Youth B stated there were no organized, recreational activities
available to youth and they sat on the unit all day, “doing nothing”.
Youth B indicated Journey To Success (JTS) was a group of
people that came to the unit to do activities and independent living
skills. However, JTS was no longer occurring. Youth B stated she
wished they did more activities and included exercise or
movement daily. Youth B reported some youth were able to go on
outings to go shopping. Youth B felt this was favoritism by staff
and not based on behavior, although she could not explain why.
Youth B wished there were more outings and fun activities
planned. However, she acknowledged that behavior of youth
impacts staff ability to do things. For example, Youth A had
frequent violent outbursts, attacking staff, breaking windows, and
fighting peers. This behavior caused staff to be busy deescalating
Youth A, rather than doing activities with the other youth. Youth B
reported police were called to the facility when youth were
physically acting out and creating weapons to hurt people. Youth
B gave the example of one youth making a “shank” with a pencil
and metal from a pencil sharpener at school. The youth attempted
to stab staff. Staff tried to talk with the youth and get the object
from them. Eventually, they contacted police for assistance. Youth
B also observed staff to call the police when a youth was suicidal,
self-harming, or swallowing things they should not, and they need
to go to the hospital to be evaluated. Staff always tried to talk to
youth and redirect them, but that did not always work. Youth B
stated police always take youth to the hospital and staff follow in
another car. When asked what the facility could change to better
3

meet the youth needs, Youth B stated they need to plan more
outings and activities to encourage the youth to have good
behavior to earn those things.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/25.
Youth C stated she participated in therapy twice a week and group
several times per week. Group consisted of journaling, talking,
and self-help worksheets. Youth C reported there were no
organized activities, since JTS was no longer active. Youth B
stated they never use the gym or go outside. They do not have
movies, games, or crafts because the girls always argued about
things. Youth C stated she often stayed in her room to read or
study for school. Youth C would like to do more activities off the
wing. However, her peer’s behavior prevented that from
happening. Youth C stated they were not punished as a group, but
when one youth would act out over several hours, it would disrupt
the plans for the day. Youth were not able to cross wings and join
activities in another wing. Youth C stated she felt they needed
more staff that are specialized in mental health crisis to assist
when youth are acting out. Youth C acknowledged that team
leaders, supervisors, and therapists were called to the unit when
there were problems. Staff would talk with youth, give them space,
and try to get them to engage in another activity, but it did not
always work. Police were called to the unit for “big stuff”, such as
when youth were self-harming, attacking staff, and breaking
windows or doors. Staff handle everything else. Youth C stated
that youth were sent to the hospital if they were injured or had
self-harmed and it was more serious than what the on-site nurse
can handle. Youth C noted if the police came to campus, youth
were automatically taken to the hospital by police. Staff always
followed the police to the hospital to stay with youth.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth D reported she felt staff were helpful and easy to talk with.
Youth D stated a typical day consists of attending school,
snacks/meals, daily therapy, and groups a few times per week.
Activities include reading, television, and movies. Youth D
reported there recently were not many organized activities or
opportunities to go outside or leave the facility for events. Youth D
did not have any concerns about the services received in the
program. Youth D reported she did not have any experience with
the police on campus, or going to the hospital. However, her
understanding was that staff would call the police for assistance if
youth were being violent, and staff could not get them to calm
down. Youth would go to the hospital if they harmed themselves
or were injured by a peer.
4

Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth E reported they participated in weekly therapy and groups a
few times per week. Youth E stated they also colored, played
games, diamond art, reading, chores, hygiene, and made phone
calls in the evening. Youth E stated staff were helpful, but
inconsistent with planning activities and addressing behaviors.
Youth E indicated staff let some youth get away with more than
others. If there were any issues, staff talk with youth and try to
help them. Youth E stated police came to the facility when youth
were assaulting people and not listening to staff. The police
always took the youth to the hospital, then staff followed and
stayed at the hospital with them. Youth E stated youth also went
to the hospital if they swallowed something or self-harmed in
another way.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Youth F reported attending therapy weekly and groups on the unit
daily. Youth F had daily phone calls to family, case worker, or
lawyer. When youth were not in school, they had some down time
and could draw or read. Youth also participated in activities that
were organized by someone that visited the unit, although she
could not recall what that was called. Youth F stated peer’s
behaviors sometimes effected their ability to have activities. Police
were called to the facility if a youth’s behavior was out of control
and staff were unsuccessful at calming them down. Police
sometimes spoke to youth and sometimes took them to the
hospital. Staff always sat with youth at the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 1 stated she believed everything was going well in the
program and the youth received the support they needed. Staff 1
stated youth participate in therapy and support groups. Youth also
color, play cards and talk to staff. Staff 1 did not think there was
anything that needed to be done differently to support youth.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 2 reported youth attend school and therapy daily and have
phone calls with family or case workers daily. Youth also have
activities such as games, drawing, coloring, listening to music, and
diamond art. Each youth could do different activities based on
their level and behavior. Staff 2 felt the program was supportive to
youth. Staff 2 stated administration was supportive to staff, and
they were provided with enough useful training to assist youth.
5

Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/17/24.
Staff 3 stated youth participate in activities such as painting
canvasses, diamond art, card games, and coloring. There was a
volunteer group that came to the unit to do scheduled activities
with youth. Youth also participate in daily therapy and groups a
few times per week. Groups included activity sheets, discussion of
issues, and understanding music lyrics. These activities were
offered to all youth, but youth did not always participate. Staff tried
to get everyone involved, but sometimes youth chose not to be.
Staff 3 stated police were called to the unit when there was
significant property damage, severe self-harming, or violent youth
that were harming people and staff were not able to successfully
deescalate. Staff would contact supervisors, as they made the
decision to call the police. If youth were taken to the hospital by
police, staff always followed. Youth were transported to the
hospital when they were self-harming. Some youth took
advantage of this and would act out to try to go to the hospital.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/24.
Staff 4 stated she often asked youth what types of activities they
would like to participate in. Typically, the youth would ask to color,
play games, build Legos, watch movies, go to the gym for
basketball or to make up cheers. A group called Heart Warmers
also came in to do organized activities with youth, such as
music/dance therapy and prayer groups. Most youth participated
in activities. However, some chose not to. Staff 4 stated they had
not experienced the police coming to the facility. However, it was
their understanding that a supervisor must decide when the police
needed to be contacted. If police transported youth to the hospital,
staff were required to stay at the hospital with the youth. Prior to
calling the police, staff would talk with youth about any issues and
try to understand what the problem was, then problem solve
before contacting a supervisor. Sometimes talking helped and
sometimes youth wanted to be alone. Staff 4 stated youth would
be taken to the hospital if they were injured, swallowed something
they should not have, or self-harmed another way.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/17/24.
Staff 5 reported youth attended school and therapy every day.
Youth participated in reflection groups a few times a week. Youth
also completed chores, had reflection time, talk with staff, and
participated in activities. Activities included arts/crafts, bingo,
trivia, and group activities that were provided by an outside group.
Staff 5 has not had any interactions with the police. However, Staff
5’s understanding was that if youth were irate or suicidal and staff
interventions have not been successful, then a team leader or
6

supervisor would be contacted. The supervisor would then make
the decision to call the police. Staff 5 was not present for any
youth that were taken to the hospital. However, Staff 5 was aware
that youth would be taken to the hospital by police if they were
suicidal or had injuries.
Chief Administrator contacted DCWL via email on 12/20/24,
outlining activities planned for youth during their holiday break
from school. Activities included Science Technology Engineering
Math (STEM) activities, basketball, holiday party, Lego activities,
movies, and a content creator workshop.
Rights Officer was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
1/15/25. Rights Officer reported the facility was partnering with
Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete on-site
screenings for Wayne MDHHS youth, to determine if they are in
need of short-term hospitalization. On 1/21/25 Rights Officer
clarified via email that JTS was a program within Vista Maria that
organized events such as groups and dances, where instructors
were brought to campus. Recently they had a hair show and a
family movie day for the youth. Dream Realized through
Education/Empowerment and Mentoring (DREAM) was a group
that was part of JTS that also offers group activities to youth on
campus. Heart Warmers was a spiritual group that youth could
participate in on Sundays. Rights Officer confirmed that all of
these groups remain active on campus.
Quality Manager was contacted via email on 1/23/25 regarding
the plans to revamp services on campus. Quality Manager
reported there was a work group developed by the Activities &
Academic Support Manager. The work group was reviewing
current activities and creating new programming activities to
engage the youth. Previously the facility contracted with outside
partners for activities. There was also a restructured client
advisory board, similar to a student council, to provide youth with
more of a voice in decisions that were made. Youth would be able
to bring any issues, concerns, wishes, requests to the group for
discussion and decision making.
Activities & Academic Support Manager (AASM) was contacted
via email on 1/23/25. AASM outlined the following items available
to youth on campus: afterschool activities include but are not
limited to, expressive therapies such as yoga, dance movement
therapy, music therapy, art therapy, physical activity and
nutritional health education. Academic mentoring and tutoring are
supported through the DREAM program as it connects each youth
7

with mentors who are successful in their career paths and provide
supports by focusing on their education and future career goals. In
addition, the activity team provides programing that creates a safe
environment to strengthen coping skills, promote social
connections, and support healthy self-esteem and confidence
through creative self-care strategies. Lastly, the Transition to
Independence Process (TIP) model, supports the youth in areas
of education, employment, social skills, relationships and health,
and life skills.
Therapist 1 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 1
reported youth at the facility were offered therapy, psychiatrist
appointments, occupational therapy, DREAM, life skills, leadership
skills, and afterschool activities such as sports, art, and dance.
Youth attended therapy twice per week on a flexible schedule that
worked best for the youth. Regarding police and hospital services,
youth were sent to the hospital when there was a suicide attempt
or AWOL. Youth may also be sent if they were highly aggressive
toward others, and staff had been unsuccessful at calming them
down. The police may be called to safely escort youth to the
hospital upon approval by the clinical supervisor and director.
Therapist 1 noted the facility was also working with Wayne County
CMH, as they could come on site to complete assessments for
youth, rather than sending the youth to the hospital.
Therapist 2 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 2
was assigned to Youth B and Youth C. Therapist 2 stated they
recently began working with these youth as their previous
therapist left the facility. Therapist 2 reported youth participated in
therapy 1-2 times per week, depending on their program. Youth
also attended group therapy, expressive therapies, recreational
therapy through Journey to Success (JTS). JTS includes Science
Technology Education Math (STEM) activities, mentoring and
educational tutoring. Youth also received occupational therapy,
psychiatric, medical, and family engagement services. While on
their unit youth were able to play games, participate in art, watch
television, and participate in groups. Therapist 2 stated Youth B
and Youth C attended therapy regularly. Although they always
engaged, Therapist 2 was still assessing them as they had only
worked together for a few weeks. Regarding police or hospital
involvement, their services may be needed if a youth was highly
escalated to an extent that it was a safety concern, and they are
unable to regulate themselves or be deescalated. Sometimes
physical intervention could be used, but that was not always safe,
especially with a youth that was self-harming or physically
8

aggressive. The unit manager, clinical director or head consulting
psychiatrist would make the determination if youth should be sent
to the hospital. Therapist 2 stated the facility began working with
Wayne County Community Mental Health to complete
assessments at the facility rather than visiting the hospital.
Therapist 2 has not had any experience with this service at this
time.
Therapist 3 was interviewed by phone on 1/23/25. Therapist 3
reported youth are offered activities such as games, art, gym,
dance class, and cooking class. Therapist 3 stated youth may feel
that they are not doing as many activities lately, but this is due to
some programs being revamped. Also, some activities may be
restricted if the youth is physically aggressive. For example,
instead of using colored pencils that may be sharp, a youth could
be given crayons to draw. Youth also attend individual and family
therapy, and occupational therapy. In therapy they work on
triggers and warning signs, coping skills, thinking/feeling, and
discussing problem solving. Regarding hospitalization and police
contact, Therapist 3 reported youth may be escorted to the
hospital by police if they had continued escalated physical
aggression, self-harming, or suicidal behavior that staff were
unable to reduce after multiple attempts to help the youth self-
regulate. The clinical supervisor and clinical director would make
the determination if assistance was to be called. Therapist 3 also
reported the facility has begun a partnership with Wayne County
CMH, where CMH staff would complete on-site assessments to
determine if a youth was eligible for short term hospitalization.
Therapist 4 was interviewed by phone on 1/24/25. Therapist 4
stated youth on campus participate in individual therapy, group
work, JTS activities, DREAM program, Alcoholics Anonymous and
Narcotics Anonymous, structured activities with volunteer groups,
occupational therapy, religious services, and receive support from
youth counselors. JTS has pro-social life skills, games, yoga,
dance, sports and art. DREAM provides life skills, vocational
training, exercise and mentorship. On the unit, youth were able to
participate in art, games, movies, crafts, activities in the courtyard,
and go on outings in the community. These activities could be
modified at times, due to youth behavioral or safety issues.
Therapist 4 stated youth receive at least one hour of therapy per
week, which may be broken up into smaller sessions, depending
on the youth. Regarding police or hospital involvement, Therapist
4 stated police have been called to campus if youth had violent
behaviors and attacked staff or peers. Police would not be called
until after staff had made several efforts to deescalate the youth. A
9

supervisor, clinical director and the psychiatrist would determine
when police would be called to campus. Generally, this decision
was made when a youth needed to be evaluated, but staff did not
feel they could safely transport the youth. Therapist 4 stated she
had some experience with the new process of having Wayne
County Community Mental Health complete an assessment on-
site, in lieu of going to the hospital. The assessment was well
done and determined the youth needed inpatient hospitalization.
However, there was not a placement available. The service was
helpful, but not as helpful as they hoped.
Documents Reviewed:
• Vista Maria Program Statement updated 3/22/2024: Direct
Program Services: “weekly individual therapy, monthly
family and group therapy, sensory integration approaches,
expressive therapies, group counseling focused on
intervention, non-violent crisis interventions approaches,
community outings, daily recreation, after-school activities,
nursing services, mentoring, life skills education, family
visitation and phone call opportunities, transportation to
home visits when appropriate, family engagement events,
and aftercare services for six months after discharge.
Contracted services include on-campus education,
psychiatric and psychological evaluations, medical, optical,
and dental examinations.”
• “Youth log of daily expectations”: Staff must indicate if
youth met expected behavior standards for the following
activities: social skills, peer interaction, school/study time,
personal care, group participation, recreation participation,
room care/chores, healthy eating, appropriate dress,
effective coping skills, safe behavior/transport.
• ‘Emergency Psychiatric Care” policy dated July 2014.
• If client is in imminent danger of harming herself or
others, supervisor/team leader/staff contacts 911.
• If the situation is serious but there is no imminent
danger, arrange for staff or private ambulance
transport to appropriate psychiatric crisis
assessment center.
• Staff should not transport an uncontrollable client. If
the situation requires it, the supervisor should call
911 for assistance.
• “Police on Campus” policy dated March 2021:
• When a situation arises that threatens the health,
safety, and welfare of our clients or staff and that is
beyond our ability to control, the police department
should be contacted for assistance.
10

• The shift supervisor or designated will contact the
police via 911.
• Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily
phone calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime”
with volunteer group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost
Voices Concert, town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace
Up Detroit, Pet Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah
Foundation, holiday decorating, and youth health fair.
• A review of MiSACWIS incident reports for the facility was
completed to confirm the youth that visited the hospital from
11/19/24-11/22/24: Youth A and Youth B.
• Case record for Youth A:
• Youth A was placed at the facility on 9/11/24
• Youth A was hospitalized from 10/25/24-11/8/24,
then returned to the facility.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24- Youth A was
removed from the facility by law enforcement after
multiple physical assaults on staff and attempts to
stab staff.
• Incident report dated 11/19/24- Youth A was
discharged from the hospital. Youth A refused to get
in the car and ran from the emergency room. 911
was contacted for assistance. Agency staff
attempted to speak with Youth A. Youth A ran, then
stole a bike and rode down the sidewalk with staff
following. Law enforcement encountered Youth A
and transported her to the facility. Youth A
threatened to kill agency staff while being
transported.
• Incident report dated 11/21/24- 9:30PM Staff walked
onto the unit and was pushed by Youth A. Youth A
attempted to wrestle facility keys away from staff.
Youth A was redirected. Youth A later made a
statement that she would choke staff. Youth A went
toward staff and was redirected. Youth A then went
after another staff pulling on them and trying to take
facility keys. Youth A then began to choke a different
staff. Two staff intervened and removed Youth A’s
hands. Youth A tried to leave the unit. Youth A then
pulled staff hair and began choking them. Team
Leader arrived and assisted in removing Youth A
from staff’s neck. Youth A then began punching
staff. Police were called and arrived at 10:10PM.
Youth A was transported by police to the hospital for
11

a psychiatric evaluation. Youth A returned to the
facility a few hours later.
• Updated Service Plan dated 11/26/24- “(Youth A)
has not quite adjusted to her placement at Vista
Maria as she often asks to go back to inpatient
hospitalization. However, the staff work to make sure
they are engaging (Youth A) in services and trying
new ways to make her comfortable. When permitted
(Youth A) engages in parenting and sibling visits that
takes place on a weekly basis. “At this time state
mental health hospitalization has been
recommended for this youth as well as partial
hospitalization due to her incline in behaviors and
medication non-compliance.”
• Documentation provided by Therapist 5 showed that
Youth A consistently attended weekly therapy.
• Case record for Youth B:
• Youth B was placed at the facility from 6/3/24-
10/21/24, hospitalized from 10/21/24-10/28/24,
returned to the facility 10/28/24-11/18/24,
hospitalized 11/18/24-11/25/24, returned to the
facility on 11/25/24.
• Incident report dated 11/18/24- Youth B transported
by ambulance due to suicidal ideation. Youth B
moved to inpatient hospitalization.
• Incident report dated 11/24/24- Youth B tied two
socks together, around her neck, stating, “I don’t
want to be here anymore”. Team Leader assisted in
removing the socks and used verbal de-escalation.
Youth B resisted staff by kicking, punching and
trying to bite them. Youth B stated, “I’m going to
keep trying to kill myself no matter what”. Youth B
began pulling scabs off her arm, causing them to
bleed. Staff attempted to verbally redirect and
deescalate. Youth B began banging her head on the
wall. Staff used a cushion behind the youth’s head.
Youth B then banged her head on the floor. Staff
used a cushion again. Youth B became aggressive,
rocking back and forth, stating she heard voices
telling her to kill herself and she planned to do it.
Law enforcement was called by the supervisor.
Youth B was transported to the hospital by the
police. Staff followed to stay at the hospital with the
youth.
• Updated Service Plan dated 10/23/24. Multiple
safety concerns regarding Youth B’s violent behavior
12

addressed in Family Team Meetings, Team Decision
Meetings, Safety Plans, and hospitalizations. Youth
B had “high suicidal and self-harm ideations that
multiple hospitalizations could not treat”. MDHHS set
up bi-weekly clinical meetings to discuss Youth B’s
progress while at the facility. Youth B struggled with
motivation to participate in the program and often
requests to go to the hospital. Youth B has bonded
with the therapist and other staff at the facility. Youth
B began Intensive Community Transition Services
and has shown improvement. Youth B remains in
mental health stabilization program at Vista Maria,
which remains the most appropriate placement. The
plan for Youth B is to be placed in an Adult Foster
Care home once progress has been made in current
program.
• Qualifying Residential Treatment Plan assessment
dated 12/5/24, indicated QRTP placement in a
Mental Health & Behavioral Stabilization program
continues to be an appropriate level of care.
• Documentation provided by Therapist 2 showed that
Youth B attended weekly therapy consistently.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance. Two youth were sent to the
hospital during the identified timeframe. Both youth were sent to
the hospital in accordance with agency policy and there was no
indication youth were not provided with services.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies; swimming
Title restriction.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency is not providing sufficient activities for youth.
Investigation During interviews, youth and staff reported there were several
activities available to youth in the program. However, Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth F reported that activities
did not always occur. Youth indicated there was increased acting
out behavior when activities did not occur, or when youth were
13

placed on wing restriction from activities. Youth reported concerns
that the agency’s behavior management/reward system was not
effective. Youth reported concerns that staff spent too much time
deescalating certain youth and therefore not completing activities
with other youth.
During interviews Youth B and Youth D reported they do not
have opportunities to participate in outdoor activities.
Activities & Academic Support Manager provided
documentation of several indoor activities made available for
youth. However, no outdoor activities were identified.
During a call on 2/6/25, Chief Administrator and Quality
Manager reported that youth participate in outdoor activity when
the weather permits. However, they were unsure if there was a
schedule of outdoor activities. They were asked to provide
documentation to show that youth were participating in outdoor
activity on a regular basis. In subsequent emails on 2/10/25 and
2/14/25, Quality Manager reported they did not have any
documentation to verify this request.
Documents Reviewed:
Weekly and monthly unit schedules were reviewed that had
schedule activities documented such as daily group, daily phone
calls, therapy, physical activity, JTS, “Chicktime” with volunteer
group, Vista Maria reads (Book Ladies), Lost Voices Concert,
town hall meeting, Boots & Bites with Lace Up Detroit, Pet
Therapy, holiday events with Abhi Shah Foundation, holiday
decorating, and youth health fair.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as youth reported being
unable to participate in activities due to peer behavior, or not
having any activities available to them while on wing restriction.
Youth also reported they are not able to engage in outdoor activity
and the agency did not have any documentation to verify outdoor
activities occur with youth.
CONSULTATION:
Consultation was offered regarding youth behavior on units that
disrupt the daily activities. When disruptive behavior is ongoing
and prohibiting other youth from their daily activities, efforts should
be made to continue activities with youth in another area, away
from the disruption. Not only would this be a positive step for the
other youth, but it would also take away the acting out youth’s
power to control the daily activity of the unit. Additionally, for youth
14

placed on restriction that are missing activities, staff should
continue to focus on encouraging the youth to reduce behaviors in
order to re-join the group. This may help alleviate the youth’s
feeling that wing restriction is never ending. Lastly, inclusion of
ideas from some restricted youth in the client advisory board
would be a great way to determine some activities that restricted
youth may be interested in, to help them increase engagement in
the program.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
